9 Sep
t
1591
M
r
Bodeley to my L.
Towching the actions of
S
r
Edward Norreys
misliked by the
states
.

page.lettertext:
fol.20r
May it please yo
r
good L. I receaved yo
r
letter of
e 23 of
e last,
e 4 of this present,
w
ch
was wholy concerning the affaires of
ostend.
Where I wishe
at
e Governo
r
could answear
every mater, as he pretendeth to yo
r
L. But
I
see it is not possible
. For all is confirmed,
by
e evidence of his actions, w
ch
are openly kno-
wen to all
e contrey: by their officers letters:
and by
e messenger himself, whome
e Governo
r
sent hither: whose declaration is made upon
his othe and alleagance, w
t
particular verifica-
tions of every mater by it self. And though
perhaps their informations may be wrong in a
point of some circumstance, yet for
e thinges
themselves they are for
e most in common practys
and notoriously knowen to all
e Garrison.
Where yo
r
L. is desirous,
at I should
send him a note of those pointes in particular,
wherew
t
he is charged by
e states, to
e end I
might be able to make answear for his doinges,
there is litle other to be said, then that w
ch
he
knoweth, and they have often objected in their
letters unto him: to w
ch
they never yet recea-
ved an answear directly. And likewise
for my self I have imparted unto him
my
by
best
advise, to w
t
drawe him from his courses, w
ch
I was certaine in
e end, if he did not alter
of himself, they would drive him therunto
by all forceable meanes. But in his answear
unto me he praied me earnestly to judge
e
best of his proceedinges, assuring he did nothing
w
t
out good warrant from her
Ma
tie
w
ch
I tooke to
be sufficient to cutte me of from all replies.
fol.20v
Nevertheles because I feared lest
e Governo
r
ether erring of his ignorance, or ill advised by others,
might endevo
r
to winne her Ma
tie
to a liking of
his actions, whereby her Hig
nes
in time might be
deepelier interessed, then I conceaved she would
be willing, if all were delivered sincerely unto
her, I thought it very requisit for discharge
of my duty, to write unto yo
r
L. as I have done
heeretofore. And though I did it not hitherto but
in general termes, yet nowe
at yo
r
L. will be
further satisfied, I have pressed
e Governo
r
in more particular maner: and have sent yo
w
e copie of suche pointes, as I have signified unto
him are offensively taken. To alleage unto him
all, in
e self same order, as they have bin presented
to
e
Councel of state
, because they are in Dutche,
it would require many leaves, and muche trans-
lation: but I have sette downe so muche, as I my
self had in memorie, and are most material.
They are not yet resolved howe to deale
w
t
e Governo
r
: and I feare in
e end they
will shewe him litle favor, for that they see no al-
teration in
e course of his government, but that
rather further mater is offered of complaint.
There are at this present certaine Burg-
masters, and other publicke officers to be chosen at
Ostend, for w
ch
this Councel doth appoint certain
Deputies to goe purposely thither: and I have mo-
ved them earnestly, to joine
M
r
Gilpin
unto
them, to
e end he might use some conference w
t
e Governo
r
, whereby they may happely be som-
what better satisfied. But they thinke that all
thinges are so evident, and
e Governo
r
so bent,
to make his gaine upon
e contrey, as I can not
fol.21r
yet persuade them, to send any man thither.
I can not ghesse at his meaning
in avowing
to yo
r
L.
at
he hath no dealing w
t
the mony due unto
e states,
but that all is gathered an d expended by their
officers there in place, wheras it is apparant,
at
sins
e 6 of Aprill last, they have not receaved
one penny of Contribution. And they make ac-
count by good conjecture (for they can not knowe
the certaintie, by reason that
e Governo
r
hath
made many secret accordes w
t
e contrey of
Flanders
) that he collecteth every moneth, all
e charges of
e fortifications defraied, not so
litle
as a thousand poundes sterlinge
. Whiche
ought to be receaved by
e states Committies,
as
e order is observed in all their other garri-
sons, w
t
out any contradiction. For it is a special
part of
e othe of every Governo
r
,
at he shall not
intermeddle w
t
disposing or receaving
e generall
meanes of
e contrey. And truly it is thought
of every man heere a very hard case, that con-
sidering w
t
what difficultie, and w
t
howe many
shiftes and devises of good husbandrie, these con-
treis doe maintene
e burdensome charge of their
warres, they should be so muche defrauded of
their publike revenue, by a privat officer of their
owne. I would it could be answeared by
e
Governo
r
in some tolerable maner. But I have
not hitherto heard any thing, by any letter from
him, as touching those affaires.
Thus I take
my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Sep
t
9 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
